channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Fernando Mendoza wins Heisman Trophy, the latest step in Indiana’s stunning rise to national prominence
item.description: The quarterback won the award Saturday night in New York over Vanderbilt quarterback Diego Pavia, Ohio State quarterback Julian Sayin and Notre Dame running back Jeremiyah Love. Mendoza’s Hoosiers, who had never had a Heisman winner, are 13-0 heading into the College Football Playoff.

item.title: At least 2 dead, 8 injured in shooting at Brown University, authorities say
item.description: Providence Mayor Brett Smiley (D) said the investigation is still ongoing and that the accounts of casualties may change. The injured victims are in critical condition, but stable, at a local hospital, Smiley said.

item.title: Suspect at large after multiple people shot around Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, police say
item.description: Students remain under lockdown, and campus and city police are responding to the incident.

item.title: What happened when Dr. Oz took charge of a wonky health agency
item.description: The former TV doctor, now running the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, has garnered positive reviews — even from some Democrats.

item.title: 2 U.S. soldiers, civilian interpreter killed during attack in central Syria
item.description: A joint U.S.-Syrian security patrol was attacked in the city of Palmyra, the Pentagon and Syria’s state news agency reported.

item.title: This former conservative journalist, now trans comedian, can take a joke
item.description: Jamie Mack came out as transgender at 49, after years of struggling with their identity. Could comedy help them work through their new life?

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: VA plans to abruptly eliminate tens of thousands of health care jobs
item.description: Strains on the Veterans Affairs system could grow with the elimination of as many as 35,000 mostly unfilled health care positions, including doctors, nurses and support staff. The cuts come after a massive reorganization effort already resulted in the loss of almost 30,000 employees this year.

item.title: DOJ report on D.C. police says chief created ‘culture of fear’ that may have tainted crime statistics
item.description: A draft report on a crime statistics investigation by U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro’s office takes aim at Pamela A. Smith, who on Monday announced her resignation.

item.title: Fired Michigan coach Sherrone Moore faces three charges, including felony
item.description: He was charged with third-degree home invasion and misdemeanor stalking and illegal entry.

item.title: Justice Department sues Georgia county as Trump pushes debunked 2020 election fraud claims
item.description: President Donald Trump has increasingly pressured his administration to find widespread voter fraud in the 2020 election, despite those claims having been debunked and dismissed in dozens of cases by the courts.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: I’m terrified my mom is going to kidnap my son
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: I’m terrified my mom is going to kidnap my son

item.title: National Trust sues to stop Trump’s ballroom construction
item.description: The organization, which is charged by Congress with historic preservation, has retained President Barack Obama’s former lawyer as it seeks to pause the project.

item.title: Secret meetings between FBI and Ukraine negotiator spark concern
item.description: FBI Director Kash Patel and his deputy, Dan Bongino, met with Kyiv’s top peace negotiator, Rustem Umerov, amid a U.S. pressure campaign to end the war.

item.title: 10 questions, and don’t forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Judge bars ICE from rearresting Kilmar Abrego García at check-in
item.description: Abrego left the ICE building to cheers from supporters shortly after a mandatory check-in at the agency’s facility in Baltimore.

item.title: Kristi Noem. AI rules. Venezuela campaign. Sudan kidnappings. Oral exams. Record cold. Tiny robots. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump signs order directing government to sue states that attempt to regulate AI — despite growing bipartisan opposition
item.description: The executive order comes as an increasing number of Republicans are speaking out against the president’s support of the tech industry’s ambitions for artificial intelligence.

item.title: Trump is expected to dramatically loosen federal restrictions on marijuana, according to six people familiar with the discussions
item.description: An executive order would direct agencies to classify marijuana as a Schedule III drug, similar to some common prescription painkillers. Rescheduling marijuana would not legalize or decriminalize cannabis, but it would ease barriers to research and boost the bottom lines of legal businesses.

item.title: Indiana redistricting effort fails as GOP lawmakers deliver rare rebuke of Trump
item.description: Some GOP state senators, who hold the majority, sided with Democrats to kill a plan to alter Indiana’s voting map, delivering President Donald Trump the biggest blow yet in his nationwide effort to create safer Republican congressional districts.

item.title: Grand jury again declines to indict New York Attorney General Letitia James, a prominent Trump foe, in mortgage fraud case
item.description: The decision marked another loss for the Trump administration as its officials attempt to charge James in a case that career prosecutors have long viewed as weak.

item.title: Senate blocks Democrats’ bill to extend ACA subsidies, all but ensuring they will expire at the end of the year
item.description: The vote was the culmination of Democrats’ months-long push to extend the subsidies and prevent premiums from rising for millions of Americans — a campaign that helped trigger the longest federal government shutdown in history. Republicans promised to hold the vote as part of a deal to end the shutdown.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Siblings at odds over funeral arrangements for abusive mother
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Siblings at odds over funeral arrangements for abusive mother

item.title: I was there when ‘Napalm Girl’ was photographed. This is what I saw.
item.description: “The Stringer” does nothing to shake my strong belief that Nick Ut captured the famous image.

item.title: Federal judge orders ‘immediate release’ of Kilmar Abrego García from ICE custody
item.description: U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis said she ordered his release in part to ensure that he had a fair immigration process after the Justice Department and an Immigration and Customs Enforcement witness last month said immigration officers had no other option but to deport him to the African nation of Liberia.

item.title: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem is expected to face tough questions on immigration at a House panel hearing
item.description: Noem’s appearance before the House Homeland Security Committee today is billed as a discussion about global threats the United States faces, but much of the focus is expected to be on her role in the Trump administration’s controversial immigration policies. Follow our live coverage and reporter insights.

item.title: A retail giant stars in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Hundreds quarantined as South Carolina outbreak accelerates in the wake of Thanksgiving travel and a lack of vaccinations
item.description: Authorities traced a sizable outbreak to a church in the state’s northwest. Of the 111 measles cases recorded in that area, 105 involved people who were unvaccinated while three involved those who were partially vaccinated, state epidemiologist Linda Bell said at a news briefing.

item.title: How a top U.S. commander decided to kill two boat strike survivors
item.description: The order given by Adm. Frank Bradley is under scrutiny from Congress. People who have viewed or been briefed on a classified video of the operation shed light on the most consequential deliberation of his career.

item.title: Oil tanker. ICE planes. Trump’s billionaires. Interest rates. ChatGPT lawsuit. Font choice. Ancient fire. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s boyfriend has had a weird month
item.description: Brian Glenn is trying not to get caught in the middle of the breakup between his partner and his president.

item.title: House passes Pentagon bill pressuring Hegseth to release boat strike evidence
item.description: The Senate could approve the measure in coming days and lawmakers are confident President Donald Trump will sign it into law.

item.title: Michigan fires football coach Sherrone Moore, citing an ‘inappropriate relationship’ with staff member
item.description: The abrupt announcement brings a stunning end to Moore’s tenure as the Wolverines’ coach after two full seasons.

item.title: U.S. seizes oil tanker off Venezuelan coast, Trump says, a significant escalation in the U.S. pressure campaign against Maduro
item.description: The seizure adds a new tactic to the Trump administration’s military campaign in waters near oil-dependent Venezuela. Since September, U.S. forces have launched strikes against more than 20 boats it alleges were carrying drugs to the United States, killing at least 87 people, while massing troops, warships and aircraft in the region.

item.title: Maryland mom ruled fit for trial 11 years after her young children vanished
item.description: Catherine Hoggle faces two counts of murder in the deaths of Jacob, 2, and Sarah, 3. She had long been considered too mentally unstable to stand before a jury.

item.title: Federal Reserve cuts rates by a quarter of a percentage point and signals at least one more cut next year
item.description: Wednesday’s widely expected move lowers the Fed’s benchmark rate to a range of 3.5 percent to 3.75 percent, the lowest level in about three years. But officials remain sharply divided over how to respond to an economy sending mixed signals.

item.title: ‘My boyfriend never tells me I’m beautiful’: Hax readers give advice
item.description: ‘My boyfriend never tells me I’m beautiful’: Hax readers give advice

item.title: This sci-fi writer predicted the future. Is he right again?
item.description: Host Megan McArdle talks to Neal Stephenson.

item.title: Our new food critic, Elazar Sontag, is taking your questions. Ask him why he’s ditching anonymity, bringing back stars and more.
item.description: Our new food critic, Elazar Sontag, is taking your questions. Ask him why he’s ditching anonymity, bringing back stars and more.

item.title: Homeland Security inks contract to create its own fleet of Boeing 737s for deportations
item.description: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement has long relied on charter planes to carry out deportation flights, but two officials familiar with the contract and records reviewed by The Washington Post indicate ICE has broader plans.

item.title: Second judge orders release of Epstein files, covering materials related to his 2019 indictment on sex-trafficking charge
item.description: Richard M. Berman, a federal judge in New York, ruled that public access is required by a law Congress passed last month. On Tuesday, another federal judge made a similar ruling covering documents involved in the prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein’s accomplice, Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: The color of the year in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Trump tour. Miami mayor. Boat strike probe. Vaccine safety. Weird weather. TikTok map. Talented octopus. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Miami elects Eileen Higgins, who is set to become the city’s first Democratic mayor in nearly 30 years
item.description: Higgins will become the first female mayor in the history of Miami. The contest attracted attention from President Donald Trump and national Democrats.

item.title: The 10 best TV shows of the year, rated by our critic
item.description: It’s been a tricky year for an embattled industry, but at least we got to watch Diego Luna, Michelle Williams, Jason Momoa and Nathan Fielder. Did your favorite show make the cut?

item.title: FDA to probe whether adult deaths are linked to coronavirus vaccine
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration’s investigation is part of a probe that has alleged children died as a result of the shots, federal health officials said. Previous reviews have found that vaccines to fight covid are generally safe.

item.title: Silver prices smash a new record, outpacing gold
item.description: The precious metal has more than doubled in value since the start of the year, rising above $60 per troy ounce on New York’s Commodity Exchange on Tuesday for the first time ever.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Father-in-law isn’t subtle about hating his grandkid’s name
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Father-in-law isn’t subtle about hating his grandkid’s name

item.title: Study shows how your brain changes at four key ages: 9, 32, 66 and 83
item.description: In a study published in the journal Nature Communications, researchers looked at about 4,000 scans from healthy people ages 0 to 90. They found four major times when the brain underwent developmental changes, dividing the lifespan into five distinct epochs.

item.title: A marriage gap is growing — and it could spell disaster
item.description: The “war on boys” could be resulting in some women shunning marriage.
